document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

C3E6D33A0212474C90C9D4E5150E0834.description:
Examine the impact and legacy of the Civil Rights Movement,
the American Indian Movement (AIM) and the women’s rights
movement today. Compare and contrast strategies and
objectives of movements today with movements in the past.

CA5F7DD1E3BC43DE8BEE5206CC161592.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

3AD6F643C3AC44CB91CB85EE257777CB.description:
Examine the impact and memory of U.S. expansion and native
dispossession today and how it’s memorialized.

B6ABF961F2CE4B35884765DF58519B3B.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

E3E3A01AD76944A68054A3C1D00E6E18.description:
Investigate the struggle for immigration rights and the rights of
all immigrants in the United States.

95A49F956E1549148C4A7C40A1999AA5.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

ADA9A4743252482AACA3B58ABE2AF88D.description:
Examine the goals and actions of community groups,
organizations and other freedom movements that fought
against injustices (i.e., local, national and global).

0A6550D2690F42A0BCB9C14527FFD8DE.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

5E5BE340D3F14C9FB1737E2675764924.description:
Examine the benefits and consequences of power and privilege
on issues associated with poverty, income and the
accumulation of wealth.

BC568D55E26047329028FFADF4259FA7.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

6C1AA43194BE41F9A212C14905BFF16B.description:
Identify a pressing contemporary issue in the student’s
community or the United States, examine its historical context
and design a plan to address it.

29E44D02D60D4E7C8C30244E016E8839.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

EFB39636FF454B8D91EC41162E9BAF30.description:
Generate a hypothesis about the impact of the Industrial
Revolution today using historical and geographic sources,
including environmental and economic impacts.

01B2884E720A473AA36043147382C4AE.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

1D1AF1454D70479788D0F3B58FCE4B58.description:
Create a timeline of major technological, economic and/or
social changes in the United States since the mid-20th century.
Analyze the intended and unintended impact of those changes.
Evaluate the relative influence of various causes of events and
developments.

D3E3C571E8514623BBA373662B14FF21.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

400B956EC8334F45ACD1EF79FB65899D.description:
Compare and contrast the central arguments in secondary
works of history to examine the changing role of the United
States on a global scale, including overseas expansion and the
impact of U.S. involvement in World War I.

77F9BB275C8D442BA583789851634F89.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

9593B99F03A4424FB1BC93A12EF11F37.description:
Construct an argument using evidence from multiple sources,
including primary sources, about the relationship between
freedom and slavery in the early U.S. Republic.

A859DF05FDB84428ABCE1761AFFEB8D6.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

7B6EDECF470D4D17BA9C7FD4BA97E6F5.description:
Evaluate the credibility of sources about a historical event
found on the internet by determining (if possible) how and why
the sources were created, how they were circulated, their
intended audience and whether the source contains citations.

E75833AC54E247A4AC19F0132A9C84A9.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

9EF92F3BE11A4E2E846840E2F475F46C.description:
Generate questions based on multiple historical sources and
identify further areas of inquiry about the Great Depression,
focusing on the impact on workers, women, and ethnic and
racial minorities.

436F7C0F2A70427985600DC147490C2F.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

EBA623EBA4334A09AE4DB1B91260B348.description:
Use historical sources to describe the strategies used by
suffragists in their campaigns to secure the right to vote.
Determine whose voices are represented and whose voices are
absent in the sources. Identify the 19th Amendment.

09B6A1AB37904813B643FF8775991C80.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

CB525377E2F54F5582EC95F039EB022D.description:
Analyze multiple perspectives (social, political, economic) about
the Cold War and describe why some perspectives may have
changed over time.

6770220DB68647B0A7E87BB878C020EA.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

5D300700D6C549128EB35553C05F898F.description:
Examine the history of U.S. expansion from multiple Indigenous
perspectives.

D461AC048EA3438DB46339F0942DEE3A.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

9E853BF6E98F4138915B83AE5D2A2D46.description:
Trace the origins of the Long Civil Rights Movement by
identifying key events and explaining their significance.

3FB85E794BDD49C9855AF238693D02C1.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

43A7B2689BD44755BC9FDF5253EC446A.description:
Analyze connections between World War II, Fascism and the
Holocaust. Identify the relationship between individuals’
experiences of these events and broader historical contexts.

EBA3A609BA7549ADAC0CA7F5B1F433D2.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

9A111B3BD3394464B49A5D72D0A6FF12.description:
Describe the effects of racism and legalized segregation on
American society, including the compromise of 1876, the rise of
“Jim Crow,” immigration restrictions and Indian Removal.

423A852BAEA14F25A8C428FC9C147662.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

28670AA946DD4F3BA6492A70575443AE.description:
Compare and contrast the impact of the Civil War and
Reconstruction on different groups in the United States and its
territories, and identify one dominant narrative and one nondominant narrative.

3784B39598E04443AA641E205FAD8709.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

9E5FD24EEFB4443291E91E3DD18189F3.description:
Evaluate political, economic, spatial and historical perspectives
used to justify the displacement/removal of Indigenous peoples
throughout the past in the United States.

AB76B4117C7E4B7BB3E6F61C6C8F10D6.description:
Culture: Investigate how
sense of place is impacted by
different cultural perspectives.

F304B782D7B44A118B3F4C2DAA3AECA1.description:
Analyze patterns of movement concerning migration of
peoples, movement of goods and ideas, trade networks, and
interconnections between places that impacted life in the
American colonies.

3EBE07BB102346BA81AB7A8C50DB0B0C.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

E9E30B8CCBF340E8A7ED75268BFEBB3F.description:
Describe how physical and human characteristics and power
structures influence the function of places over time.

B75C995C33174D3882532975B495ABF0.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

2074E8AEA2E9489BBD059B10DC7C54B8.description:
Investigate spatial questions to make claims and support them
with evidence from maps.

A7BAC6A0855440109D7EFE5D35EBCC80.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

5B8F93A6637A47F08BE9D00530E621C0.description:
Create and evaluate fixed and dynamic maps from different
places, times and perspectives using geospatial technologies.

8A08D192B7814B45938E636F996A3E6B.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

52B98F46993C4AC791E7A70E1CBC0DAA.description:
Distinguish between groups that benefit and that are hurt by a
specific trade policy.

D284469FCA764968A670C97654780CC3.description:
Global and International:
Explain why people trade and
why nations encourage or limit
trade. Analyze the costs and
benefits of international trade
and globalization on communities
and the environment.

FF888808B7F94D9C927C8861CBB5CEE5.description:
Explain how profit can be an incentive for entrepreneurs to
develop medical breakthroughs, new technology, green energy
and other benefits to society, but the profit motive can also
lead to negative outcomes including resource exploitation and
unfair labor practices.

A9B8750B15ED4BF2B0488D1AB35C915D.description:
Microeconomics: Explain and
evaluate how resources are used
and how goods and services are
distributed within different
economic systems. Analyze how
incentives influence the decisions
of consumers, producers, and
governments. Evaluate the
intended and unintended
consequences of these decisions
from multiple perspectives.

BC523EC9E82849FD9F864D3831EABF09.description:
Apply reasoned decision-making techniques, using primary
sources. Explain why different groups across different cultures
and communities may prioritize different values when faced
with the same alternatives.

A0FFABDD38494A85AB2CAECB9165412D.description:
Personal Finance: Apply
economic concepts and models
to develop individual and
collective financial goals and
strategies for achieving these
goals, taking into consideration
historical and contemporary
conditions that either inhibit or
advance the creation of individual
and generational wealth.

302500C63FA44C3EA24BDE6395A933D3.description:
Explain different ways that goods and services can be allocated
when scarcity exists.

7F3E4A8C8F084F2EBAABFA1AE66E7972.description:
Fundamental Economic
Concepts: Analyze how scarcity
and artificial shortages force
individuals, organizations,
communities, and governments
to make choices and incur
opportunity costs. Analyze how
the decisions of individuals,
organizations, communities, and
governments affect economic
equity and efficiency.

0165B66A8D504AF9AF4796669401E9E1.description:
Using cost-benefit analysis, analyze the opportunity cost of a
decision made in U.S. history during times of war.

ADD7E36E8F99424DB7C3A4CCDB401364.description:
Economic Inquiry: Use
economic models and reasoning
and data analysis to construct an
argument and propose a solution
related to an economic question.
Evaluate the impact of the
proposed solution on various
communities that would be
affected.

30C9475091B34255A4B65F2DA45F2924.description:
Explain the impacts of treaties and policies from the
perspectives of the United States and Tribal Nations and
analyze ways in which Tribal Nations are seeking to enforce
treaty rights.

201D60EC9CE8401483A1FA33B3E0E1FB.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

151A2DEEA9A34AB7B61D778957BCABB2.description:
Explain how political parties, interest groups, various types of
media and public opinion shape public policy formation.

2AF87A03BBC8428D9C0636CD0EBC7A86.description:
Public Policy: Analyze how
public policy is shaped by
governmental and nongovernmental institutions.
Analyze how people and
communities take action to solve
problems and shape public policy.

8C96CBA739564EFCB2A692DDFD8F7CB7.description:
Describe how laws are created. Classify the differences
between civil, criminal, tribal and juvenile law. Give examples of
local, state, federal and tribal laws. Describe the constitutional
amendment process and the impact of voting amendments to
explain changes in voting laws and election processes.

9447E83E9C7C4E788715C87A32B3488A.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

2AF6E5EC9D3B4A2CA8475439BC1B9762.description:
Explain landmark Supreme Court decisions involving the Bill of
Rights and other individual protections. Explain how these
decisions helped define the scope and limits of personal,
political and economic rights.

9C676B0D9F1845F3897171EB837BCBBA.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

65016477C84A4D7EB930C34ABF73022E.description:
Evaluate how well principles expressed in the Declaration of
Independence and preamble to the U.S. Constitution have been
applied throughout United States history, including how they
have evolved (if applicable) over time.

D71A02F36C0A4B4C950B9452925B5309.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

20F1BFC927AB4EAF91CD0BBFEAC78D5C.description:
Participate in civil discourse on issues in the contemporary
United States and evaluate arguments including identifying pros
and cons.

2BFB5600017D4D95BAB4E4670DC47C6C.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
